{{Cannabis sidebar}} Different religions have varying stances on the use of [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]], historically and presently. In ancient history some religions used cannabis as an [[entheogenic]], particularly in the [[Indian subcontinent]] where the tradition continues on a more limited basis. In the modern era, religions with prohibitions against intoxicants, such as Islam, Buddhism, Bahai, Latter-day Saints (Mormons), and others have opposed the use of cannabis by members, or in some cases opposed the liberalization of cannabis laws. Other groups, such as some Protestant and Jewish factions, have supported the use of [[medicinal cannabis]]. ==Bahá'í== In the [[Bahá'í Faith]], use of alcohol and other drugs for intoxication, as opposed to medical prescription, is prohibited,{{cite journal|author1=Khali Akhtar Khavari|author2=Teresa McCray Harmon|title=The Relationship between the Degree of Professed Religious Belief and Use of Drugs|journal=International Journal of the Addictions|volume=17|issue=5|pages=847–857|date=1982|doi=10.3109/10826088209056331}} see [[Bahá'í laws]]. But Bahá'í practice is such laws should be applied with "tact and wisdom".{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= law |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 1-85168-184-1 |pages= 223–225}} The use of tobacco is an individual decision, it is yet strongly frowned on and not explicitly forbidden.{{cite book|author=Udo Schaefer|title=In a blue haze, smoking and Bahá'í ethics|publisher=Zero Palm Press|edition=Translated from the original German language edition: Ethische Aspekte des Rauchens. Ein Beitrag zur Bahá'í-Ethik published by Bahá'í Verlag, Hofheim 21993 by Michael H. Machado and Dr. Craig Volker.|date=1997|url=http://bahai-library.org/books/bluehaze/index.html|chapter-url=http://bahai-library.org/books/bluehaze/8.html|chapter=`Abdu'l-Bahá's judgement|isbn=80-901201-5-6}} Bahá'í authorities have spoken against intoxicant drugs since the earliest stages of the religion, with [[‘Abdu’l-Bahá]] writing: {{quote|Regarding [[hashish]] you have pointed out that some Persians have become habituated to its use. Gracious God! This is the worst of all intoxicants, and its prohibition is explicitly revealed. Its use causeth the disintegration of thought and the complete torpor of the soul. How could anyone seek the fruit of the infernal tree, and by partaking of it, be led to exemplify the qualities of a monster? How could one use this forbidden drug, and thus deprive himself of the blessings of the All-Merciful? Alcohol consumeth the mind and causeth man to commit acts of absurdity, but this opium, this foul fruit of the infernal tree, and this wicked hashish extinguish the mind, freeze the spirit, petrify the soul, waste the body and leave man frustrated and lost.[http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-187.html Notes #170. The use of opium - any substance that induceth sluggishness and torpor], ''The Kitáb-i-Aqdas'', by Bahá’u’lláh, published by Bahá’í World Centre, 1992 edition, Pages: 254}} ==Buddhism== In Buddhism, the [[Five Precepts|Fifth Precept]] is frequently interpreted to mean "refrain from intoxicating drinks and drugs which lead to heedlessness", although in some direct translations, the Fifth Precept refers specifically to alcohol.{{cite book | last = Yin-Shun | first = Venerable | editor = Wing H. Yeung, M.D. | title = The Way to Buddhahood: Instructions from a Modern Chinese Master | publisher = Wisdom Publications | year = 1998 | isbn = 0-231-11286-6 | pages=86–87}} Cannabis and some other psychoactive plants are specifically prescribed in the [[Mahakala|Mahākāla]] [[Tantras|Tantra]] for medicinal purposes.Stablein WG. The Mahākālatantra: A Theory of Ritual Blessings and Tantric Medicine. Doctoral Dissertation, Columbia University. 1976. p 21-2,80,255-6,36,286,5. ==Christianity== ===Catholicism=== Prior to assuming his position as leader of the [[Catholic Church]], [[Pope Francis]] had spoken against recreational cannabis. He stated in 2013 in Buenos Aires: "A reduction in the spread and influence of drug addiction will not be achieved by a liberalization of drug use."{{cite news|last=Bindrim|first=Kira|title=Pope Francis Speaks Out Against Legalization of Marijuana and Other Drugs|url=http://www.newsweek.com/pope-francis-says-he-opposes-marijuana-legalization-255708|magazine=[[Newsweek]]|date=June 20, 2014|accessdate=September 19, 2018}} The catechism of the Catholic Church states that "The use of drugs inflicts very grave damage on health and life. Their use, except on strictly therapeutic grounds, is a grave offense."{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/_P80.HTM |title=Catechism of the Catholic Church |publisher=Libreria Editrice Vaticana |date= |accessdate=2018-05-18}} ===The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints=== {{main|Cannabis and Latter-day Saints}} In [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]], there is general prohibition against intoxicating substances. In August 1915, the LDS Church banned the use of cannabis by its members. In 2016, the church's [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]] urged members to oppose legalization of recreational cannabis use.{{cite news|last=West|first=Camille|title=First Presidency Asks Members to Oppose Recreational Marijuana, Assisted Suicide|url=https://www.lds.org/church/news/first-presidency-asks-members-to-oppose-recreational-marijuana-assisted-suicide?lang=eng|publisher=Intellectual Reserve, Inc.|website=LDS.org|date=October 14, 2016|accessdate=September 19, 2018}} The LDS Church says it has "raised no objection to SB 89" (non-psychoactive medical marijuana in Utah).{{cite press release|title=Church Urges 'Cautious Approach' on Medical Marijuana Issue in Utah|url=https://www.mormonnewsroom.org/article/church-urges-cautious-approach-medical-marijuana-issue-utah|publisher=Intellectual Reserve, Inc.|website=MormonNewsroom.org|date=February 12, 2016|accessdate=September 19, 2018}}{{cite news|last=Wells|first=David|title=LDS Church issues new statement on medical marijuana|url=http://fox13now.com/2016/02/12/lds-church-clarifies-stance-on-medical-marijuana/|publisher=[[KSTU]]|website=Fox13Now.com|date=February 12, 2016|accessdate=March 6, 2017}} ===Orthodoxy=== The [[Georgian Orthodox Church]] has resisted legalization of cannabis in that country.http://neweasterneurope.eu/articles-and-commentary/2276-fighting-georgia-s-draconian-anti-drug-law ===Protestantism=== The [[Arkansas Baptist State Convention]] voted to discourage medical marijuana in 2016.{{cite web|author=Tom Strode |url=http://www.bpnews.net/47842/marijuana-legalization-on-9-state-ballots |title=Marijuana legalization on 9 state ballots |publisher=Bpnews.net |date= |accessdate=2017-03-06}} In 2016, the executive director of the [[Florida Baptist Convention]], Tommy Green, also said that congregations should be encouraged to vote against [[Florida Amendment 2 (2016)|expanded legalization of medical marijuana in Florida]]. The National Evangelical Association of Belize opposed the 2017 decriminalization of [[cannabis in Belize]].http://www.guardian.bz/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=14372:churches-complain-about-marijuana-law&catid=40:politics&Itemid=90 The [[Assemblies of God USA]], as well as other [[Pentecostalism|Pentecostal]] and [[Holiness Movement|holiness churches]], have historically advocated abstinence from all alcohol, tobacco, and narcotics. Supporters of this view generally cite biblical passages enjoining respect for one's body as well as forbidding intoxication.{{cite web | url = http://ag.org/top/Beliefs/topics/charctr_08_drugs.cfm | title = Alcohol, Tobacco & Drugs | last = | first = | date = | website = ag.org | publisher = Assemblies of God USA | access-date = April 10, 2017 }} Other Protestant churches have endorsed the legality of medical marijuana, including the [[Presbyterian Church (USA)]], [[United Methodist Church]], [[United Church of Christ]], and the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]].{{cite web|last=Bosch |first=Torie |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/2007/03/what_would_jesus_smoke.html |title=What do Christian groups think about marijuana? |work=Slate |date=2007-03-20 |accessdate=2017-03-06}} ==Hinduism== {{main|Cannabis in India}} [[File:Ganja Smoking - Gangasagar Fair Transit Camp - Kolkata 2013-01-12 2646.JPG|thumb|right|250px|A [[Hindu]] man smoking cannabis in [[Kolkata, India]].]] During the [[Hindu]] festival of [[Holi]], people consume ''bhang'' which contains cannabis flowers.{{cite book|title=Report of the Indian Hemp Drugs Commission|year=1894|location=Simla, India|publisher=Government Central Printing House|url=http://www.druglibrary.net/schaffer/Library/studies/inhemp/4chapt9.htm}} Chapter IX: Social and Religious Customs.{{cite web |url=http://www.skunked.co.uk/articles/history-intoxicant.htm |title=The History of the Intoxicant Use of Marijuana |publisher=National Commission of Marijuana and Drug Abuse |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050813080240/http://www.skunked.co.uk/articles/history-intoxicant.htm |archivedate=2005-08-13 |df= }} According to one description, when the ''[[amrita]]'' (elixir of life) was produced from the [[Samudra manthan|churning of the ocean]] by the devas and the asuras, [[Shiva]] created cannabis from his own body to purify the elixir (whence, for cannabis, the epithet ''angaja'' or "body-born"). Another account suggests that the cannabis plant sprang up when a drop of the elixir dropped on the ground. Thus, cannabis is used by [[rishi|sages]] due to association with elixir and [[Shiva]]. [[File:Bhang eaters before two huts (6124556163).jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Bhang]] eaters from India c. 1790. Bhang is an [[cannabis edible|edible preparation]] of [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] native to the [[Indian subcontinent]]. It has been used in food and drink as early as 1000 BCE by [[Hindu]]s in [[ancient India]].{{cite web|url=https://munchies.vice.com/en_us/article/kbx94a/httpmunchies-vice-comarticlesthe-bhang-lassi-is-how-hindus-drink-themselves-high-for-shiva |title=The Bhang Lassi Is How Hindus Drink Themselves High for Shiva |author=Staelens, Stefanie |website=Vice.com |accessdate=August 10, 2017}}]] In Hinduism, wise drinking of ''bhang'' (which contains cannabis), according to religious rites, is believed to cleanse sins, unite one with [[Shiva]] and avoid the miseries of [[Naraka (Hinduism)|hell]] in the [[Saṃsāra|future life]]. It is also believed to have medicinal benefits. In contrast, foolish drinking of ''bhang'' without rites is considered a sin.{{cite web|url=http://www.druglibrary.org/schaffer/LIBRARY/studies/Inhemp/7relhemp.htm|title=Indian Hemp Drugs Commission Report - Appendix}} ==Islam== {{Main|Halal|Islamic dietary laws}} The [[Quran]] does not directly forbid cannabis; however, cannabis is deemed to be ''[[khamr (intoxicant)|khamr]]'' (an intoxicant) by many religious scholars and therefore generally believed to be ''[[haraam]]'' (forbidden).{{cite book|last=Abdul-Rahman|first=Muhammad Saed|title=Islam: Questions and Answers - Pedagogy Education and Upbringing|publisher=MSA Publication Limited|year=2003|page=123| isbn= 978-1-86179-296-9 }}{{cite book|author=Pakistan Narcotics Control Board, Colombo Plan Bureau|title=First National Workshop on Prevention and Control of Drug Abuse in Pakistan 25–30 August 1975|location=Rawalpindi|publisher=Workshop Report|year=1975|page=54}} A [[hadith]] by the prophet Mohammed states: "If much intoxicates, then even a little is haraam."AD 25;5 Despite these prohibitions, cannabis is consumed in many parts of the Islamic world, even sometimes in a religious context particularly within the [[Sufi]] mystic movement.{{cite book|author=Mark S. Ferrara|title=Sacred Bliss: A Spiritual History of Cannabis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t1wdDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA45|date=20 October 2016|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-1-4422-7192-0|pages=45–}} In 1378 [[Soudoun Sheikouni]], the Emir of the Joneima in Arabia, prohibited cannabis, considered one of the world's first-attested cannabis bans.{{cite book|author=Bankole A. Johnson|title=Addiction Medicine: Science and Practice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zvbr4Zn9S9MC&pg=PA303|date=10 October 2010|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1-4419-0338-9|pages=303–}} The Sufi tradition attributes the discovery of cannabis to [[Jafar Sharazi]] (Sheikh Haydar), a Sufi leader in the 12th century.{{cite book|author=Nick Jones|title=Spliffs: A Celebration of Cannibis Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=abK_CAAAQBAJ&pg=PT36|date=29 July 2013|publisher=Pavilion Books|isbn=978-1-909396-32-6|pages=36–}} Other Sufis attribute its origin to the apocryphal [[Khidr]] ("Green Man").{{cite book|author=Michael Muhammad Knight|title=Journey to the End of Islam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9XM4AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA62|date=10 December 2009|publisher=Soft Skull Press|isbn=978-1-59376-552-1|pages=62–}} Some modern Islamic leaders state that medical cannabis, but not recreational, is permissible in Islam. Imam Mohammad Elahi in [[Dearborn Heights]], Michigan (United States), declared: "Obviously, smoking marijuana for fun is wrong... It should be permissible only if that is the only option in a medical condition prescribed by medical experts."{{cite web|last=Hijazi |first=Samer |url=http://www.arabamericannews.com/news/news/id_12118/Marijuana-in-Islam:-Smokers-and-scholars-weigh-in.html |title=Marijuana: Arab Smokers, religious scholars weigh in |publisher=Arabamericannews.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-13}} ==Judaism== {{main|Cannabis and Judaism}} Though the argument has not been accepted by mainstream scholars, some writers have theorized that cannabis may have been used ritually in early Judaism, though these claims "have been widely dismissed as erroneous".(Merlin, 2003)[[Economic Botany]] [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1663/0013-0001(2003)057%5B0295:AEFTTO%5D2.0.CO%3B2#page-1 M. D. Merlin Archaeological Evidence for the Tradition of Psychoactive Plant Use in the Old World - University of Hawaii] "23 May 2011 - ".. Judaism (Dure 2001; Merkur 2000), and Christianity (Allegro 1970; Ruck et al. 2001). Although this hypothesis and some of the specific case studies (e.g., Allegro 1970) have been widely dismissed as erroneous, others continue" [[Sula Benet]] (1967) claimed that the plant ''kaneh bosm קְנֵה-בֹשֶׂם'' mentioned five times in the Hebrew Bible, and used in the [[holy anointing oil]] of the Book of Exodus, was in fact cannabis,Rowan Robinson, The Great Book of Hemp, Health & Fitness, 1995, pag. 89 although lexicons of Hebrew and dictionaries of plants of the Bible such as by [[Michael Zohary]] (1985), [[Hans Arne Jensen]] (2004) and [[James A. Duke]] (2010) and others identify the plant in question as either ''[[Acorus calamus]]'' or ''[[Cymbopogon citratus]]''.Lytton J. Musselman ''Figs, dates, laurel, and myrrh: plants of the Bible and the Quran'' 2007 p73 In the modern era, Orthodox rabbi [[Moshe Feinstein]] stated in 1973 that cannabis was not permitted under Jewish law, due to its harmful effects.{{cite book|author=Julian G. Jacobs|title=Judaism looks at modern issues|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mVIRAQAAIAAJ|year=1993|publisher=Aviva Press|isbn=978-0-9511560-2-5}}{{cite book|author=Mitch Earleywine|title=Pot Politics: Marijuana and the Costs of Prohibition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fgASDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA218|year=2007|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|isbn=978-0-19-518802-8|pages=218–}}{{cite book|author=Fred Rosner|title=Biomedical Ethics and Jewish Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T7w2oAmohpEC&pg=PA92|year=2001|publisher=KTAV Publishing House, Inc.|isbn=978-0-88125-701-4|pages=92–}} However Orthodox rabbis [[Efraim Zalmanovich]] (2013) and [[Chaim Kanievsky]] (2016) stated that medical, but not recreational, cannabis is kosher.{{cite news|author=Elsa Vulliamy |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/marijuana-is-kosher-for-passover-leading-rabbi-rules-a6995761.html |title=Marijuana is kosher for Passover, leading rabbi rules |publisher=The Independent |date=2016-04-22 |accessdate=2017-02-13}} ==Rastafari== It is not known when [[Rastafari]] first claimed cannabis to be sacred, but it is clear that by the late 1940s Rastafari was associated with cannabis smoking at the Pinnacle community of [[Leonard Howell]]. Rastafari see cannabis as a sacramental and deeply beneficial plant that is the [[Tree of Life]] mentioned in the [[Bible]]. [[Peter Tosh]], among many others, has quoted {{bibleref2|Revelation|22:2}}, "... the herb is the healing of the nations." The use of cannabis, and particularly of long-stemmed water-pipes called [[chalice (pipe)|chalices]], is an integral part of what Rastafari call "reasoning sessions" where members join together to discuss life according to the Rasta perspective. They see the use of cannabis as bringing them closer to [[God]] ([[Jah]]), allowing the user to penetrate the truth of things more clearly. While it is not necessary to use cannabis to be a Rastafari, many use it regularly as a part of their faith, and pipes of cannabis are dedicated to His Imperial Majesty [[Haile Selassie I]] before being smoked. According to the [[Anti-cult movement|anti-cult group]] the [[Watchman Fellowship]] "The herb is the key to new understanding of the self, the universe, and God. It is the vehicle to cosmic consciousness"{{citation |url= http://www.watchman.org/profile/rastapro.htm |title= Rastafarianism |work= Profiles |publisher= [[Watchman Fellowship|Watchman Fellowship ministry]] |first= Rick |last= Branch |year= 2000 }} and is believed to burn the corruption out of the human heart. Rubbing the ashes into the skin from smoked cannabis is also considered a healthy practice.{{cite book|authorlink=Joseph Owens (Jesuit)|title=Dread, The Rastafarians of Jamaica|year=1974|isbn=0-435-98650-3|first=Joseph|last=Owens}} Part of the Rastafari movement, elders of the 20th-century religious movement known as the [[Ethiopian Zion Coptic Church]], consider cannabis to be the "eucharist",{{cite web|url=http://nepenthes.lycaeum.org/Drugs/THC/bible.html|title=Marijuana and the Bible|publisher=[[Ethiopian Zion Coptic Church]]}} claiming it as an oral tradition from [[Ethiopia]] dating back to the time of Christ.{{cite web|url=http://www.erowid.org/plants/cannabis/cannabis_spirit2.shtml|title=Erowid Cannabis Vault : Spiritual Use #2}} ==Scientology== [[Scientology]] opposes the use of cannabis, and made "Truth About Marijuana" the focus of their 2016 [[World Health Day]] presentation.{{cite web|url=http://www.scientologynews.org/press-releases/activity/church-hosts-truth-about-marijuana-event.html |title=Church Hosts "Truth About Marijuana" Event |publisher=Scientologynews.org |date=2016-04-18 |accessdate=2017-02-13}} ==Sikhism== {{main|Cannabis and Sikhism}} [[File:Process of making bhang in Punjab, India.jpg|thumb|Process of making bhang in a Sikh village in Punjab, India.
Photos taken by Marcus Prasad]] In [[Sikhism]], the First Sikh Guru, [[Guru Nanak]], stated that using any mind altering substance (without medical purposes) is a distraction to keeping the mind clean of the name of God.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} According to the ''[[Sikh Rehat Maryada]]'', "A Sikh must not take hemp (cannabis), opium, liquor, tobacco, in short any intoxicant. His only routine intake should be food and water".{{cite web|url=http://www.amritworld.com/main/?p=82#sthash.agD98t5F.dpbs|title=The ‘Sukhnidhaan’ or ‘Bhang’ (cannabis)|work=Amrit World|accessdate=19 November 2015}} However, there exists a tradition of Sikhs using edible cannabis, often in the form of the beverage [[bhang]], particularly among the Sikh community known as [[Nihang]].{{cite book|author1=Pashaura Singh|author2=Louis E. Fenech|title=The Oxford Handbook of Sikh Studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8I0NAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA378|date=March 2014|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-969930-8|pages=378–}}{{cite book|author1=Pashaura Singh|author2=Michael Hawley|title=Re-imagining South Asian Religions: Essays in Honour of Professors Harold G. Coward and Ronald W. Neufeldt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4SLhLakpsNsC&pg=PA34|date=7 December 2012|publisher=BRILL|isbn=90-04-24236-8|pages=34–}} ==Taoism== Beginning around the 4th century, Taoist texts mentioned using cannabis in [[censer]]s. Needham cited the (ca. 570 AD) Taoist encyclopedia ''Wushang Biyao'' 無上秘要 ("Supreme Secret Essentials") that cannabis was added into ritual incense-burners, and suggested the ancient Taoists experimented systematically with "hallucinogenic smokes".Needham and Lu (1974), [https://books.google.com/books?id=TTHGp0euKmoC&pg=PA150&lpg=PA150#v=onepage&q=&f=false p. 150]. From ancient Chinese fumigation techniques with "toxic smokes" for pests and "holy smokes" for demons, "what started as a 'smoking out' of undesirable things, changed now to a 'smoking in' of heavenly things into oneself." The ''Yuanshi shangzhen zhongxian ji'' 元始上真眾仙記 ("Records of the Assemblies of the Perfected Immortals"), which is attributed to [[Ge Hong]] (283-343), says: :For those who begin practicing the Tao it is not necessary to go into the mountains. … Some with purifying incense and sprinkling and sweeping are also able to call down the Perfected Immortals. The followers of the Lady Wei and of Hsu are of this kind.Needham and Lu (1974), p. 152. Lady [[Wei Huacun]] 魏華存 (252-334) and Xu Mi 許謐 (303-376) founded the Taoist [[Shangqing School]]. The Shangqing scriptures were supposedly dictated to [[Yang Xi]] 楊羲 (330-c. 386) in nightly revelations from [[Xian (Taoism)|immortals]], and Needham proposed Yang was "aided almost certainly by cannabis". The ''Mingyi bielu'' 名醫別錄 ("Supplementary Records of Famous Physicians"), written by the Taoist pharmacologist [[Tao Hongjing]] (456-536), who also wrote the first commentaries to the Shangqing canon, says, "Hemp-seeds (麻勃) are very little used in medicine, but the magician-technicians (''shujia'' 術家) say that if one consumes them with [[ginseng]] it will give one preternatural knowledge of events in the future."Needham and Lu (1974), [https://books.google.com/books?id=TTHGp0euKmoC&pg=PA151&lpg=PA151#v=onepage&q=&f=false p. 151].{{cite book|first=Richard|last=Rudgley|url=http://cannabis.net/hist/index.html|title=The Encyclopedia of Psychoactive Substances|publisher=Little, Brown and Company|year=1998}} A 6th-century AD Taoist medical work, the ''Wuzangjing'' 五臟經 ("Five Viscera Classic") says, "If you wish to command demonic apparitions to present themselves you should constantly eat the inflorescences of the hemp plant."Joseph Needham, Ho Ping-Yu, and Lu Gwei-djen (1980). ''Science and Civilisation in China: Volume 5, Chemistry and Chemical Technology; Part 4, Spagyrical Discovery and Invention''. Cambridge University Press, [https://books.google.com/books?id=JvLroG7r2MYC&pg=PA213#v=onepage&q=&f=false p. 213]. Joseph Needham connected myths about [[Magu (deity)|Magu]], "the Hemp Damsel", with early Daoist religious usages of cannabis, pointing out that Magu was goddess of [[Shandong]]'s [[Sacred Mountains of China|sacred]] [[Mount Tai]], where cannabis "was supposed to be gathered on the seventh day of the seventh month, a day of seance banquets in the Taoist communities."Needham, Joseph. 1974. [https://books.google.com/books?id=TTHGp0euKmoC ''Science and Civilisation in China: Volume 5, Chemistry and Chemical Technology; Part 2, Spagyrical Discovery and Invention: Magisteries of Gold and Immortality'']. Cambridge University Press, p. 152 ==Other cannabis-using religious movements== Other religions have been founded in the past century that treat cannabis as a sacrament. They include the [[Santo Daime]] church, the [[THC Ministry]], Cantheism, the Cannabis Assembly, the Church of Cognitive Therapy (COCT Ministry), Temple 420, Green Faith Ministries, the [[Church of Cognizance]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v08/n848/a01.html|last=Innes|first=Stephanie|title=Pot-Deifying Duo Guilty, Confident They'll Avoid Prison|date=2008-09-05|work=[[Arizona Daily Star]]|publisher=[[Lee Enterprises]]}} the [[Church of the Universe]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v08/n1046/a05.html|last=Jackson|first=Hayes|title=Appeal Date Set For Pot Priests|work=[[The Hamilton Spectator]]|year=2008|publisher=[[Torstar]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.iamm.com|title=Church of the Universe|publisher=[[Church of the Universe]]}} the Free Marijuana Church of Honolulu, the First Cannabis Church of Florida World Wide,[http://www.cannabischurchfl.com/ First Cannabis Church of Florida] the Free Life Ministry Church of Canthe, the Church of Higher Consciousness, and the federally tax-exempt inFormer Ministry Collective of Palms Springs, CA.{{cite web|url=http://www.informer.org|title=InFormer Ministry}}{{cite web|url=http://www.informer.org/9900001.jpg|title=Rev. Dennis Erlich's inFormer Ministry Collective IRS 990-N registration form.}} The Temple of the True Inner Light believes that cannabis is one of the parts of God's body, along with the [[Serotonergic psychedelic|classical psychedelics]]: [[mescaline]], [[psilocybin]], [[Lysergic acid diethylamide|LSD]], and [[Dimethyltryptamine|DMT]].{{cite web|title=Temple of the True Inner Light|url=http://psychede.tripod.com}} The [[First Church of Cannabis Inc.]] officially gained legal recognition in Indiana in 2015 following the passage of that state's [[Religious Freedom Restoration Act]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/First-Church-of-Cannabis-Approved-After-Passing-of-Indianas-New-Religious-Freedom-Law-298477321.html|title=First Church of Cannabis Approved After Passing of Indiana's New Religious Freedom Law}} Nonprofit religious organization Elevation Ministries opened its [[Denver]] headquarters, known as the [[International Church of Cannabis]], on [[420 (cannabis culture)|April 20]], 2017.[http://www.thecannabist.co/2017/04/12/international-church-of-cannabis-elevationists-denver-social-use-law/77127/ This new cannabis church pushes limits of Denver’s social-use pot law][http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/international-church-cannabis-elevationists-denver_us_58eff016e4b0b9e9848ab45a International Church Of Cannabis Prepares For Opening Day] Modern spiritual figures like [[Ram Dass]]{{cite web|url=http://www.drugpolicy.org/library/ramdass.cfm |title=Ram Dass: Longtime Spiritual Leader, Opponent of the 'War on Drugs' |date=2004-03-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080920210640/http://drugpolicy.org/library/ramdass.cfm |archivedate=2008-09-20 |df= }} openly acknowledge that the use of cannabis has allowed them to gain a more spiritual perspective and use the herb frequently for both its medicinal and mind-altering properties. In Mexico, followers of the growing cult of [[Santa Muerte]] regularly use marijuana smoke in purification ceremonies, with marijuana often taking the place of incense used in mainstream Catholic rituals.{{cite web|url=http://www.ktsm.com/news/only-9-the-dark-religion-santa-muerte |title=Only on 9: The Dark Religion of the Santa Muerte | KTSM News Channel 9 |publisher=Ktsm.com |date=2009-03-26 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} ==See also== {{Portal|Cannabis}} * [[Religion and drugs]] * [[Charas]] * [[Entheogenic drugs and the archaeological record]] * [[Free Exercise Clause]] * [[Freedom of thought]] * [[Magu (deity)]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * [[Martin Booth|Booth, Martin]]. (2004). ''Cannabis: A History''. St. Martin's Press. {{ISBN|0-312-32220-8}} * Shields, Rev. Dennis (1995). ''The Holy Herb''. Source: {{cite web|url=http://www.hialoha.com/konagold/church/holyherb.html |title=The Religion of Jesus Church - The Holy Herb |publisher=Hialoha.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711164716/http://www.hialoha.com/konagold/church/holyherb.html |archivedate=2011-07-11 |df= }} *Bennett, Chris, "Cannabis and the Soma Solution", (Trineday, 2010) {{ISBN|0984185801}} *Bennett, Chris; McQueen, Neil, "Sex, Drugs, Violence and the Bible" (Forbidden Fruit Publishing.com) {{ISBN|1550567985}} * Bennett, Chris; Lynn Osburn & Judy Osburn (1995). ''Green Gold the Tree of Life: Marijuana in Magic & Religion.'' CA: Access Unlimited. {{ISBN|0-9629872-2-0}} * ''The Sacred Plants of our Ancestors'' by [[Christian Rätsch]], published in [[Tyr (journal)#Volume 2|TYR: Myth—Culture—Tradition Vol. 2]], 2003–2004 - {{ISBN|0-9720292-1-4}} * Jackson, Simon (2007). ' 'Cannabis & Meditation - An Explorer's Guide'. Headstuff Books. {{ISBN|978-0-9553853-1-5}}. Second Edition (2009) {{ISBN|978-0-9553853-4-6}} ==External links== * [http://www.erowid.org/plants/cannabis/cannabis_culture2.shtml Nectar of Delight: The Early History of Cannabis], from ''Plants of the Gods'' by Schultes & Hofmann * [http://www.cannabisculture.com/content/2016/08/15/cannabis-in-ancient-greece Cannabis in Ancient Greece] by Chris Bennett, August 2016 * [http://www.erowid.org/plants/cannabis/cannabis_spirit6.shtml Resurrection of the Higher Self] by Matthew Webb, July 1989 * [https://www.elevationists.org/about Elevation Ministries], based in Denver, Colorado * [http://www.greenfaithministry.com/ Greenfaith Ministry], based in Nunn, Colorado * [http://thehealingchurchri.com/ The Healing Church], Catholic organization in Providence, Rhode Island {{Cannabis and religion}} {{Cannabis resources}} {{Hallucinogens}} {{Religion topics}} [[Category:Entheogens]] [[Category:Cannabis and religion| ]] [[Category:Ceremonial food and drink]] [[Category:Religion and health]]

{{Infobox criminal | name = Christa Pike | nationality = [[United States|American]] | birth_name = Christa Gail Pike | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1976|03|10|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[West Virginia]] | education = | conviction = [[Conspiracy (crime)|Conspiracy to commit murder]],
[[Murder]] — March 22, 1996 | conviction_penalty = [[Capital punishment|Death]] — March 30, 1996 | conviction_status = Awaiting execution on [[death row]] | parents = Glenn Pike and Carissa Hansen | relatives = Unnamed half-sister | motive = [[Jealousy]] | time_at_large = 2 days | victims = Colleen Slemmer | date = January 12, 1995 | locations = [[University of Tennessee]] | states = [[Tennessee]] | country = [[United States]] | injuries = | weapons = Box Cutter & Rock | apprehended = {{start date and age|1995|01|14}} | imprisoned = }} '''Christa Gail Pike''' (born March 10, 1976) is the youngest woman to be [[death penalty|sentenced]] to death in the [[United States]] during the post-[[Furman vs. Georgia|Furman]] period.{{cite news|url=http://www.chattanoogan.com/2016/3/11/319852/Chattanooga-Federal-Judge-Upholds.aspx|title=Chattanooga Federal Judge Upholds Conviction of Christa Pike, Who Carried out Torture Murder Of Romantic Rival|access-date=June 6, 2017|newspaper=The Chattanoogan|date=March 17, 2016}} She was 20 when convicted of the [[torture murder]] of a classmate she committed at age 18. Pike lived a troubled life and dropped out of high school. She joined the [[Job Corps]], a government program aimed at helping low-income youth by offering vocational training and career skills, and attended the now-closed Job Corps center in [[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville]], [[Tennessee]]. Pike fell for a young man named Tadaryl Shipp, one year her junior. Together they "dabbled" in the [[occult]] and [[devil worship]].{{cite news|url=http://www.willkern.com/pike.html|title=Angel's Face, Devil's Heart|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]]|date=April 22, 2001|author=Will Kern}} == Crime == Pike became jealous of 19-year-old fellow student Colleen Slemmer, who she thought was trying to "steal" her boyfriend from her; friends of Slemmer deny the accusations. Along with friend Shadolla Peterson, 18, Pike planned to lure Slemmer to an isolated, abandoned steam plant close by on the [[University of Tennessee]] campus. On January 12, 1995, Pike, Shipp, Peterson, and Slemmer signed out of the [[dormitory]] and proceeded to the woods, where Slemmer was told they wanted to make peace by offering her some [[marijuana]]. Upon arrival at the secluded location, Slemmer was attacked by Pike and Shipp while Peterson acted as lookout. Per later court testimony, for the next thirty minutes Slemmer was taunted, beaten, and slashed, and a [[pentagram]] was carved in her chest.[http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2008/dec/21/rejected-appeal-for-pike-revealing Rejected Appeal], Knoxville News Dec 21 2008[http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2008/apr/07/hearing-convicted-job-corps-killer-pike-resumes Hearing Resumes], Knoxville News April 7, 2008 Finally, Pike smashed Slemmer's skull with a large chunk of [[asphalt]], killing her. Pike kept a piece of her victim's skull. Pike began to show off the piece of skull around the school, and within thirty-six hours the three were arrested. The log book showed that the four of them left together and only three returned. They also found the piece of skull in Pike's jacket pocket. The girls' rooms were searched and a copy of the ''[[Satanic Bible]]'' was found in Shipp's. Pike insisted they were merely trying to scare her and it got out of control. == Trial == There was evidence and a confession. Pike was charged with [[murder]] and conspiracy to commit murder. On March 22, 1996 after only a few hours of [[deliberation]], Pike was found guilty on both counts. On March 30, 1996, Pike was sentenced to death by electrocution for the murder charge and 25 years in [[prison]] for the conspiracy charge. Shipp received a life sentence with the possibility of [[parole]] in 2028. Peterson, who had turned [[informant]], received probation for pleading guilty to being an accessory. == Appeal of conviction == Following the guilty verdict, Pike "launched, cancelled and then re-launched" an appeal of her conviction in the Tennessee state courts.[http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2008/dec/11/judge-denies-pikes-appeal Judge Denies Appeal], Knoxville News Dec 11 2008 In June 2001, then again in June 2002, against the advice of her lawyers, Pike asked the courts to drop her appeal and sought to be executed via electrocution. Criminal Court Judge Mary Beth Leibowitz granted the request and an execution date of August 19, 2002, was set.[http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/062702/met_9772184.html Execution Date Set], Florida Times Union June 27, 2002, Pike soon thereafter changed her mind and on July 8, 2002, defense lawyers filed a motion to allow the appeal process to continue. This motion was denied. However, on August 2, 2002 a three judge state appeals court panel ruled that the proceedings should be continued and the execution was not carried out.{{cite web |url=http://www.tcask.org/news/christa.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202090922/http://www.tcask.org/news/christa.htm |archivedate=2008-12-02 |df= }} In December 2008, Pike's latest request for a new trial was turned down and she was returned to death row. This denied request is believed to be the final allowed under the appeals procedures in the State of Tennessee.[http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2007/dec/04/final-death-row-appeal-christa-gail-pike-delayed-a Pike's Final Appeal], Knoxville News Dec 4 2008 As of May 2014, no execution date has been set and her case has now entered the federal court system.{{cite web |url=http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2013/feb/13/killer-christa-gail-pike-asks-fed-court-to-block/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140608070933/http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2013/feb/13/killer-christa-gail-pike-asks-fed-court-to-block/ |archivedate=2014-06-08 |df= }} A federal court has denied a request to release and overturn the death penalty conviction.Mike Donila: [http://www.wbir.com/news/local/federal-court-denies-pikes-request-to-overturn-death-penalty/77588963 Federal court denies Pike's request to overturn death penalty], [[WBIR-TV]], 11 March 2016 == Attempted murder conviction == On August 24, 2001, Pike (with alleged assistance from inmate [[Natasha Cornett]]) attacked and attempted to strangle fellow inmate Patricia Jones with a shoe string, and nearly succeeded in choking her to death. She was convicted of attempted first degree murder on August 12, 2004.[http://www.state.tn.us/correction/media/womendeathrow.html ''Women on Death Row''], Tennessee Department of Correction. Although it is the position of the Tennessee Department of Corrections that Natasha assisted in this crime, their investigators concluded there was insufficient evidence to charge her with helping Pike attack Jones.[http://www.prisontalk.com/forums/archive/index.php/t-18901.html Love and Hate on Death Row, The Tennessean July 6 2003], Available on Prison Talk Online == Attempted prison break == In March 2012, it was revealed that Pike had made escape plans involving corrections officer Justin Heflin and a New Jersey man named Donald Kohut. Kohut had visited Pike in prison, but complete details of his relationship to Pike were not immediately known. The attempted prison break was thwarted by a joint investigation involving the Tennessee Department of Corrections, the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation and the New Jersey State Police. {{cite web |url=http://www.ksdk.com/news/crime/article/311792/147/Death-row-inmate-woos-NJ-man-and-guard-to-help-plan-escape |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130127053544/http://www.ksdk.com/news/crime/article/311792/147/Death-row-inmate-woos-NJ-man-and-guard-to-help-plan-escape |archivedate=2013-01-27 |df= }} ==In popular culture== The murder of Colleen Slemmer was featured on ''[[Deadly Women]]'', ''[[Killer Kids]]'', ''[[Killed by Gossip]]'', ‘’[[For My Man]]’’ and ''[[Snapped: Killer Couples]]''. ==See also== *[[List of women on death row in the United States]] *[[List of death row inmates in the United States]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pike, Christa}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American criminals]] [[Category:American female murderers]] [[Category:American murderers]] [[Category:American female criminals]] [[Category:American people convicted of attempted murder]] [[Category:American people convicted of murder]] [[Category:American prisoners sentenced to death]] [[Category:Crimes involving Satanism or the occult]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Tennessee]] [[Category:People from West Virginia]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to death by Tennessee]] [[Category:Women sentenced to death]] [[Category:Violence against women in the United States]] [[Category:1995 murders in the United States]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2010}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = Danny Carey | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | image = Danny_Carey_and_his_drum-kit.jpg | image_size = 250 | landscape = yes | caption = Danny Carey and his drums. | birth_name = Daniel Edwin Carey | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1961|5|10}} | birth_place = [[Lawrence, Kansas]] | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Progressive metal]] * [[progressive rock]] * [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] * [[art rock]] * [[alternative metal]] }} | occupation = {{flatlist| * Musician * songwriter }} | instrument = {{flatlist| * Drums * percussion * tabla * guitar * bass * synthesizer }} | label = {{flatlist| * [[Zoo Entertainment (record label)|Zoo Entertainment]] * [[Volcano Records|Volcano II]] }} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Tool (band)|Tool]] * [[Pigmy Love Circus]] * [[Volto!]] * [[Zaum (band)|Zaum]] * [[Green Jellÿ|Green Jellö]] * [[Primus (band)|Primus]] * Legend of the Seagullmen }} | website = {{URL|dannycarey.org}} }}
'''Daniel Edwin Carey''' (born May 10, 1961) is an American drummer and instrumentalist best known for his work in American Grammy Award-winning [[progressive metal]] band [[Tool (band)|Tool]]. He has also contributed to albums by artists such as [[Zaum (band)|Zaum]], [[Green Jellÿ|Green Jellö]], [[Pigface]], [[Skinny Puppy]], [[Adrian Belew]] of [[King Crimson]], [[Carole King]], [[Collide (band)|Collide]], [[Free Mars|Lusk]], and the [[The Melvins|Melvins]].
==Biography== Born in [[Lawrence, Kansas]], Carey's first encounter with the drums began at the age of ten by joining the school band and taking private lessons on the [[snare drum]].<ref name="tdn">{{cite web | url=http://toolshed.down.net/bio/dannybio.php | title = The Tool Page: Danny Carey Biography | first = Joel | last=Mahaffey | work= The Tool Page (t.d.n) | date = August 6, 2001}}</ref> Two years later, Carey began to practice on a [[drum set]]. In his senior year of high school in [[Paola, Kansas]], Carey joined the high school jazz band. Jazz would later play a huge role in his signature approach to the drum set in a rock setting. As Carey progressed through high school and later college at the [[University of Missouri–Kansas City]], he began expanding his studies in percussion with theory into the principles of geometry, science, and metaphysics as well as delving into [[Sacred Geometry]] and certain hidden aspects of life and the [[occult]]. Carey also played jazz while attending college and got to experience the jazz scene in [[Kansas City Jazz|Kansas City]].
After college, a friend and bandmate convinced Carey to leave Kansas for [[Portland, Oregon]], where he played briefly in various bands before moving to [[Los Angeles]], where he was able to perform as a studio drummer with [[Carole King]] and perform live sets with [[Pigmy Love Circus]]. He also played in Green Jellö as Danny Longlegs and recorded the album ''Cereal Killer''. He would later find his way to [[Tool (band)|Tool]] after coming to know singer [[Maynard James Keenan]] and guitarist [[Adam Jones (musician)|Adam Jones]] and practicing with them in place of drummers the two had requested but had never shown up. Besides Tool, Carey also finds time for other projects new and old such as Legend of the Seagullmen, Pigmy Love Circus, [[Volto!]], and [[Zaum (band)|Zaum]].
==Religion and the occult== Although Carey has not officially aligned himself with any particular school of philosophy or religion, he has projected a deep interest in and understanding for the [[Magick (Thelema)|magickal]] arts – among them various occult teachings. [[Enochian]] symbols, geometric designs, and special symbolic percussive devices are featured on and in his drum kit. He is also a collector of First Edition [[Aleister Crowley]] books as well as books by one of Crowley's more innovative students, [[Kenneth Grant]].
===Geometric designs=== Carey has laid claim to various drumming techniques that use sacred geometric figures such as the [[unicursal hexagram]]. The final product is very recognizable, fluent drumming, although to him it is much more: the official Tool website claims that Danny uses drumming as a ritual similar to occult rituals,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.toolband.com/identity/danny/main.html |title=Official Tool website – Danny Carey's personal profile |publisher=Toolband.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003172448/http://www.toolband.com/identity/danny/main.html |archivedate=October 3, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> with purposes varying from spiritual exploration to "a gateway [which] summoned a daemon he has contained...that has been delivering short parables similar to passages within ''[[The Book of Lies (Crowley)|The Book of Lies]]''". Another geometric reference from the website was the inclusion of ''Nothing in This Book Is True...'' by Bob Frissell<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bobfrissell.com |title=Bob Frissell's home page |publisher=Bobfrissell.com |date=October 1, 2011 |accessdate=2011-10-09}}</ref> on the band's recommended reading list, a book that deals with sacred geometry and the evolution of human consciousness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toolshed.down.net/community/newsletter/letter.fall.94.html |title=Fall 1994 newsletter |publisher=Toolshed.down.net |date= |accessdate=2011-10-09}}</ref>
==Side projects and other musical endeavors== In his time away from Tool, Carey has contributed (and still regularly does) to a vast number of projects: *Fusion band [[Volto!]], which regularly plays shows in the Los Angeles area, consisting of both covers and original material.{{Citation needed|date=June 2013}} *[[Pigmy Love Circus]], which has recorded several albums *[[Electronica]]-oriented project [[Zaum (band)|Zaum]] *[[Green Jellÿ|Green Jellö]] *[[Pigface]] *Drums on the track "Use Less" from the album ''[[The Greater Wrong of the Right]]'' by [[Skinny Puppy]] *Contributed to [[Adrian Belew]]'s ''[[Side One]]'' and ''[[Side Three]]'' projects with bassist [[Les Claypool]] *Drums on certain tracks of the Carole King album ''[[Colour of Your Dreams]]'' (as a session drummer) with [[Velvet Revolver]] guitarist [[Slash (musician)|Slash]] playing on select tracks *Drums on the track "Somewhere" from the [[Collide (band)|Collide]] album ''[[Some Kind of Strange]]'' and several tracks from [[Two Headed Monster (album)|Two Headed Monster]] *Made an appearance on the 1997 album ''[[Free Mars]]'' by former Tool bassist [[Paul D'Amour]]'s band [[Lusk (band)|Lusk]] *Drums on the track "The Fourth" on the self-titled album from Feersum Ennjin, the band of former Tool Bassist [[Paul D'Amour]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.revolvermag.com/news/exclusive-feersum-ennjin-premiere-the-fourth-featuring-tools-danny-carey.html|title=Exclusive: Feersum Ennjin Premiere "The Fourth," Featuring Tool’s Danny Carey|author=Geist|first=Brandon|date=November 17, 2011|website=|publisher=Revolver Magazine|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303224305/http://www.revolvermag.com/news/exclusive-feersum-ennjin-premiere-the-fourth-featuring-tools-danny-carey.html|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=yes|accessdate=October 9, 2012}}</ref> *Drums with psychedelic rock supergroup Legend of the Seagullmen along with [[Brent Hinds]] of [[Mastodon (band)|Mastodon]] and others, their eponymous debut album is set to be released on February 9, 2018 on Dine Alone Records.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UuQtN3vk-q8</ref>{{update inline|date=November 2018}}
==Equipment== Carey uses the wood tip version of his own signature model of drumstick made by [[Vic Firth]].<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.vicfirth.com/products/signatureseries1.php |title=vicfirth.com |publisher=vicfirth.com |date= |accessdate=November 10, 2014}}</ref> He previously had endorsed a signature model with Trueline Drumsticks (now Trueline's Tribal Assault model.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.truelinedrumsticks.com |title=truelinedrumsticks.com |publisher=truelinedrumsticks.com |date= |accessdate=October 9, 2012}}</ref>)
At Winter [[NAMM Show|NAMM]] 2009 [[Sonor]] released a Danny Carey signature snare drum, which is a 1 mm thick bronze 14x8" snare with laser etched talisman symbols and his signature engraved around the vent hole.
Carey also uses [[Paiste]] cymbals, [[Evans Drumheads]], Hammerax Percussion, and [[Korg]] and [[Roland Corporation|Roland]] electronics.
==Drumming techniques== Carey's popularity among drummers and non-drummers alike stems from the diversity of his sound and dynamics through his years of learning jazz music, his technical ability, frequent use of odd time signatures, [[polyrhythm]]s and polymeters. He has stated in interviews that he effectively treats his feet as he does his hands: he practices [[rudiments]] (used for sticking techniques) and even snare drum solos with his feet to improve his [[bass drum|double bass]] drumming, hi-hat control and foot independence.
In search of new techniques, Carey has studied [[tabla]] with [[Aloke Dutta]], who can be heard playing on the live version of the song "Pushit" (from ''[[Salival]]''). This is especially apparent on tracks such as "Disposition" (''[[Lateralus]]'') or "Right in Two" (''10,000 Days''), for which Carey has recorded the tabla parts himself in the studio. The tabla (and other percussive instruments) used in Tool's music are replicated live using the [[Mandala pad]]s (in fact the pads are also used when recording in the studio, a notable example being the tabla solo of "Right in Two" from ''10,000 Days'').
He has also stated that when he is playing to an odd time signature, he tries to drum to the "feel" of the song and establish general "inner pulse" for the given time signature instead of fully counting it out.
Carey has been featured in many drum and music magazines.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.moderndrummer.com/updatefull/200001157/Danny%20Carey |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913101941/http://www.moderndrummer.com/updatefull/200001157/Danny%20Carey |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 13, 2009 |title=Danny Carey: Artists: Modern Drummer Magazine |publisher=Moderndrummer.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-09 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

'''Garbhodakaśāyī Vishnu''' is an expansion of [[Mahavishnu|Mahā Vishnu]]. In [[Gaudiya Vaishnavism|Gaudīya Vaishnavism]] the Sātvata-tantra describes three different forms of Vishnu as: [[Maha Vishnu|Mahā Vishnu]], Garbhodakaśāyī Vishnu and [[Ksirodakasayi Vishnu|Ksirodakaśāyī Vishnu]] ([[Paramatma|Paramātmā]]). Each form has a different role in the maintenance of the Universe and its inhabitants.
"For material creation, Lord [[Krishna]]'s plenary expansion assumes three Vishnus. The first, [[Mahavishnu|Mahā Viṣhṇu]], creates the total material energy, known as the mahat-tattva. The second, Garbhodakaśāyī Viṣṇu, enters into all the [[universes]] to create diversities and the third, [[Ksirodakasayi Vishnu|Kṣīrodakaśāyī Vishnu]], is diffused as the all-pervading super soul in all the universes; in the heart of every living being, is known as Paramātmā. He is present even within the [[atom]]s.The real objective of [[meditation]] in [[Yoga]] is attaining a state of Paramātmā. Anyone who realises them can be liberated from material entanglement."<ref>[http://bhagavadgitaasitis.com/7/4/en1 Quoted from the Sātvata-tantra] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311062325/http://bhagavadgitaasitis.com/7/4/en1 |date=2007-03-11 }} translation by A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupāda</ref>
Garbhodhakaśāyī Viṣṇu is an expansion or overload of [[Mahavishnu|Mahā Viṣṇu]] (expansion of [[Sankarshana|Saṃkarṣaṇa]] of second caturvyūha, which expands from [[Narayana|Nārāyaṇa]] in [[Vaikunta|Vaikuṇṭhaloka]]). Garbhodhakaśāyī Vishnu is realized as the form of [[Pradyumna]] within the material universe . He is the father of Brahmā who appeared from His navel and hence Garbhodakashayi Vishnu is also called Hiraņyagarbha.

'''Goverdhan Puja''' <ref name="Livingston">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_WZJCgAAQBAJ|title=The Hidden Revelation: "My passion is Spirituality; my mission is to end homelessness and hunger."|last=Livingston|first=Morson|date=2015-07-10|publisher=Xlibris Corporation|isbn=9781503584082|language=en}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C8HcBvE8XJ4C|title=Absent Lord: Ascetics and Kings in a Jain Ritual Culture|last=Babb|first=Lawrence A.|date=1996-08-01|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520917088|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://festivals.iloveindia.com/diwali/govardhan-puja.html|title=Govardhan Puja - Govardhan Puja Legends, Govardhan Pooja Celebrations|website=festivals.iloveindia.com|access-date=2016-04-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BWQMBAAAQBAJ|title=Seeing Krishna in America: The Hindu Bhakti Tradition of Vallabhacharya in India and Its Movement to the West|last=Richardson|first=E. Allen|date=2014-07-29|publisher=McFarland|isbn=9780786459735|page=187|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":0"/> as it is also known, is a [[Hindu festival]] in which devotees prepare and offer a large variety of vegetarian food to Bhagwan (God) Shri Krishna as a mark of gratitude.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Hindu Rites & Rituals|last=Mukundcharandas|first=|publisher=Swaminarayan Aksharpith|year=2007|isbn=81-7526-356-3|location=India|pages=357}}</ref> For [[Vaishnavism|Vaishnavas]], this day commemorates the incident in the [[Bhagavata Purana|Bhagavata Puran]] when Bhagwan Shri Krishna lifted the Govardhan Hill to provide the villagers of Vrindavan shelter from torrential rains. The incident is seen to represent how God will protect all devotees who take singular refuge in him.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.baps.org/News/2000/3rd-Guinness-World-Record-for-Annakut-1926.aspx|title=3rd Guinness World Record for Annakut|website=BAPS Swaminarayan Sanstha|access-date=2016-04-01}}</ref> Devotees offer a mountain of food, metaphorically representing the Govardhan Hill, to God as a ritual remembrance and to renew their faith in taking refuge in God.<ref name="Livingston"/> The festival is observed by most of Hindu denominations all over India and abroad. For Vaishnavas this is one of the important festivals. For the Vallabh Sampradaya ([[Pushtimarg]]),<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BWQMBAAAQBAJ|title=Seeing Krishna in America: The Hindu Bhakti Tradition of Vallabhacharya in India and Its Movement to the West|last=Richardson|first=E. Allen|date=2014-07-29|publisher=McFarland|isbn=9780786459735|page=25|language=en}}</ref> the Gaudiya Sampradaya of Chaitanya,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BWQMBAAAQBAJ|title=Seeing Krishna in America: The Hindu Bhakti Tradition of Vallabhacharya in India and Its Movement to the West|last=Richardson|first=E. Allen|date=2014-07-29|publisher=McFarland|isbn=9780786459735|page=26|language=en}}</ref> and the Swaminarayan Sampradaya etc among others.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/leicester/content/articles/2007/11/13/annakut_diwali_feature.shtml|title=Annakut Celebration!|last=BBC|language=en-gb|access-date=2016-04-01}}</ref> The Annakut festival occurs on the first lunar day of [[Shukla Paksha]] (bright fortnight) in the Hindu calendar month of [[Kartik (Nepali calendar)|Kartik]], which is the fourth day of [[Diwali|Deepawali]] (Diwali), the Hindu festival of lights, and also the first day of the [[Vikram Samvat]] calendar.<ref name="Livingston"/><ref>{{Cite book|title=Hindu Rites and Rituals: Sentiments, Sacraments and Symbols.|last=Mukundcharandas|first=|publisher=Swaminarayan Aksharpith|year=2007|isbn=81-7526-356-3|location=India|pages=104}}</ref>[[File:Annakut.jpg|thumb|Annakut feast]]
The 2017 date for this observance is October 20.
==Origins of Govardhan Puja and Annakut== [[File:Krishna Holding Mount Govardhan - Crop.jpg|thumb|Krishna holding Mount Govardhan]] Krishna spent most of his childhood in [[Braj]], a place devotees associate with many of Krishna’s divine and heroic exploits with his childhood friends.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PyC4o7i9tnEC|title=India: A Sacred Geography|last=Eck|first=Diana L.|date=2013-03-26|publisher=Three Rivers Press|isbn=9780385531924|page=361|language=en}}</ref> One of the most significant incidents, described in the [[Bhagavata Purana]],<ref name=":0" /> involves Krishna lifting Mount Govardhan (Govardhan Hill), a low hill situated in the middle of Braj.<ref name=":0" /> According to the Bhagavata Purana, forest-dwelling [[gopi|cowherds]] living close to [[Govardhan]] used to celebrate the autumn season by paying respect to [[Indra]], the God of rain and storm. Krishna did not approve of this since he desired that the villagers worship Mount Govardhan with the reason that Mount Govardhan is the one that provides natural resources to the villagers for their livelihood. Trees provided oxygen, the grass provided food for the cattle and provided natural beauty. The mountain was responsible for the natural phenomena that occur in the city of Gokul. Indra got angry with this advice. Shri Krishna, though being younger than almost everyone in the city, was respected by everyone due to his knowledge and immense power. So, the people of Gokul agreed with Shri Krishna's advice. Indra was angered upon seeing the villagers' devotion diverted away from him and toward Krishna. Indra decided to initiate thunderstorms and heavy rains in the city in reflex of his egoistic anger. To protect the people from the storms, Shri Krishna lifted the Govardhan mount on his little finger and provided shelter to all the people and cattle of the city. After 7–8 days of continuous storms, seeing the people of Gokul being unaffected, Indra accepted defeat and stopped the storms. This day is therefore celebrated as a festival that paid respect to Mount Govardhan by preparing a 'giriyajna' - a "great offering of foods and delicacies to the mountain" Krishna then assumed the form of a mountain himself and accepted the villagers' offerings. .<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://basr.ac.uk/diskus_old/diskus11/wood.htm|title=DISKUS: The journal of the British Association for the Study of Religions (BASR)|website=basr.ac.uk|access-date=2016-04-01}}</ref> Indra, after causing torrential rains for seven days, ultimately gave up and bowed to Krishna’s superiority.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> This story is one of the most recognizable in the Bhagavata Purana.<ref name=":0" />
Govardhan has since become a major pilgrimage site in Braj for devotees of Krishna.<ref name=":0" /> On the day of Annakut, devotees circumambulate the hill and offer food to the mountain—one of the oldest rituals in Braj.<ref name=":0" /> The circumambulation consists of an eleven-mile trek dotted along the way with several shrines, before which devotees place flowers and other offerings.<ref name=":0" />
Families create an image of Giriraj Govardhan (the mountain) from cow dung, adorning it with miniature cow figures as well as grass as twigs, representing trees and greenery.<ref name=":0" /> In the days leading up to Annakut, fifty-six food items (chappan bhog) are typically prepared and offered in the evening.<ref name=":0" /> Someone from a cow-herding caste officiates the ritual, circling the hill with a cow and a bull, followed by families in the village. They partake in the sanctified food after offering the food to the hill. The festival often draws a large crowd, including the [[Chaube]] [[brahmin]]s of [[Mathura]].<ref name=":0" />
== Rituals Of Annakut == Annakut is celebrated on the fourth day of Diwali. The fourth day of Diwali is also the first day of the new year in the Vikram Samvat calendar. Therefore, the rituals surrounding Annakut are closely linked with the rituals of the five days of Diwali. While the first three days of Diwali are days of prayer to sanctify wealth and invite greater wealth into the devotee’s life, the annakut day is a day of offering gratitude for Krishna beneficence
=== Goverdhan Puja === Govardhan Puja is a principal ritual performed during Annakut. Although some texts treat Govardhan Puja and Annakut as synonymous, the Govardhan Puja is one segment of the day-long Annakut festival.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3KcEotmV2MAC|title=Guests at God's Wedding: Celebrating Kartik among the Women of Benares|last=Pintchman|first=Tracy|date=2005-08-25|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=9780791465950|pages=212, 66|language=en}}</ref>
There are many variants of how Govardhan Puja is performed. One ritual is performed in which a god is (Lord Krishna)makes from cow dung in horizontal position.After, completing the structure it is decorated by earthernlamps(deepak or diya),the seenkh(a material which is same as the broom's chaff),candles and after worshiping,the structure of lord is feed by the bhaktas or worshipersand the ladies do fasts<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://festivals.iloveindia.com/diwali/govardhan-puja.html|title=Govardhan Puja - Govardhan Puja Legends, Govardhan Pooja Celebrations|website=festivals.iloveindia.com|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref> Prayers are also made to Lord Govardhan.<ref name=":3" />[[File:Govardhan -1.JPG|thumb|Govardhan -1]]
As described in the Bhagavata Purana , Govardhan Puja is chiefly identified with Krishna lifting the Govardhan Hill on his finger to protect those who sought his refuge from Indra’s torrential rage.<ref name="basr.ac.uk">{{Cite web|url=http://basr.ac.uk/diskus_old/diskus11/wood.htm|title=DISKUS: The journal of the British Association for the Study of Religions (BASR)|website=basr.ac.uk|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3KcEotmV2MAC|title=Guests at God's Wedding: Celebrating Kartik among the Women of Benares|last=Pintchman|first=Tracy|date=2005-08-25|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=9780791465950|page=212|language=en}}</ref>
=== Main Annkut Festival === Vast array of vegetarian foods is traditionally arranged in tiers or steps in front of the deities.<ref name="basr.ac.uk" /> Usually, the sweets are placed nearest to the Deities. As the tiers descend, other foods such as '[[dal]]', vegetables, pulses and fried savory foods are arranged. A mound of cooked grains, symbolic of Mount Govardhan, is placed in the center. In Swaminarayan shikharbaddh mandirs, sadhus begin to arrange the Annakut in the morning and finish before noon.<ref name="swaminarayan.org">{{Cite web|url=http://www.swaminarayan.org/festivals/diwali/index2.htm|title=Nutan Varsh - Annakut (New Year's Day)|website=www.swaminarayan.org|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref>
=== Thaal === In all [[Swaminarayan]] mandirs, sadhus and devotees then sing 'Thaal' - [[kirtan]]s or devotional hymns composed by the poet paramhansas of Swaminarayan. These kirtans describe the food items, and are about praying to the Deities to accept the food. The singing lasts for about an hour, and is followed by a grand arti.<ref name="swaminarayan.org"/> Afterwards, devotees do puja and circumambulate the Deities and offered food.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G9D40mqdvgMC|title=The Power of the Dharma: An Introduction to Hinduism and Vedic Culture|last=Knapp|first=Stephen|date=2006-06-05|publisher=iUniverse|isbn=9780595837489|language=en}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}}</ref> In some mandirs, Arti is performed several times in the day as long as the Annakut offerings remain before the Deities. In the evening, devotees take portions of the Annakut as prasad, sanctified food, that has been offered to God and is received as his mercy.<ref name="swaminarayan.org"/>
In certain mandirs, especially in Mathura and Nathadwara, the murtis are also given a [[milk bath]] before being and dressed in elegant clothes and ornaments.<ref name="Rosen">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WuVG8PxKq_0C|title=Essential Hinduism|last=Rosen|first=Steven|date=2006-01-01|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=9780275990060|language=en}}</ref>
=== Vishvakarma Puja === Some craftsmen pay reverence to their tools and machinery on the day of Annakut.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g4TtrdejbTEC|title=Festivals of India|date=2002-01-01|publisher=Har-Anand Publications|isbn=9788124108697|language=en}}</ref>
==Annkut Celebrations Today== Hindus throughout the world actively celebrate Annakut as a part of Diwali and, most frequently, pair the Annakut celebration with the Govardhan Puja performed on fourth day of Diwali celebrations.<ref name="Livingston"/> Hindus also view Annakut as a time to transmit religious and cultural values to children, ask for forgiveness from God and express devotion towards God. Annakut is celebrated with [[Diya (lamp)|diya]]s (small oil lamps) and [[rangoli]], decorative art on the ground made from colored rice, colored sand, and/or flower petals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bapsgermany1.blogspot.com/2014/10/annakut-at-baps.html|title=BAPS Germany: Annakut at BAPS|last=Germany|first=Baps|website=BAPS Germany|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref> Many distinct food items, sometimes numbering in the hundreds or thousands, are offered to deities during Annakut.<ref name=":2" /> For example, 250 kilograms of food were offered to Lord Krishna at the [[ISKCON]] temple in Mysore, India in 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/govardhan-puja-at-iskcon-temple/article163949.ece|title=Govardhan puja at ISKCON temple|date=2009-10-19|newspaper=The Hindu|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref> Although Annakut is most often associated with Lord Krishna, other deities are also focal points.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/9680810/Diwali-2012-London-temple-welcomes-Hindu-New-Year-with-a-mountain-of-food.html|title=Diwali 2012: London temple welcomes Hindu New Year with a mountain of food|website=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://mahalakshmi-temple.com/festival.asp|title=Shri Mahalaksmi Temple Charities - Festivals and special arrangements|last=Designs|first=Enlighten|website=mahalakshmi-temple.com|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref> At the Shree Mahalakshmi Mandir in Mumbai, India, 56 sweets and food items are offered to Mataji and then distributed as Prasad to more than 500 devotees.<ref name=":4" />
The Annakut festival is also celebrated annually at approximately 3,850 [[BAPS]] Mandirs and centers throughout the world in a day-long event. During the festival, Swaminarayan devotees prepare and offer a large variety of vegetarian food to Hindu deities including Swaminarayan and Krishna, among others.<ref name=":5"/> The Annakut festival at BAPS mandirs is often the largest festival of the year.<ref name=":5"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.baps.org/News/2013/Annakut-Celebrations-2013-5407.aspx|title=Annakut Celebrations 2013|website=BAPS Swaminarayan Sanstha|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.baps.org/News/2014/New-Year---Annakut-Celebrations-with-Pramukh-Swami-Maharaj-6936.aspx|title=New Year - Annakut Celebrations with Pramukh Swami Maharaj|website=BAPS Swaminarayan Sanstha|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/local-news/birmingham-hundreds-people-marked-hindu-8014681|title=In Birmingham hundreds of people marked Hindu New Year and Diwali|last=Fulford|first=Paul|website=birminghammail|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://parsippanyfocus.com/2014/10/28/diwali-celebrations-baps-parsippany/|title=Diwali Celebrations at BAPS Parsippany|last=Staff|first=Parsippany Focus|website=Parsippany Focus|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref> Visitors learn about Hindu spirituality, offer prayers for the new year, partake in the prasad, or sanctified food, and engage in other devotional activities.<ref name="Rosen"/> A devotee at the BAPS Swaminarayan Mandir in [[Leicester]], England, which organizes the Annakut festival every year, describes Annakut as being a forum where spiritual aspirants can reaffirm their appreciation for the role God plays in their lives.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/leicester/content/articles/2007/11/13/annakut_diwali_feature.shtml|title=Annakut Celebration!|last=BBC|language=en-gb|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref> These gatherings also represent an opportunity to reaffirm a sense of community.<ref name=":5" /> At the BAPS Swaminarayan Mandir in Neasden, England in 2004, 1247 vegetarian dishes were assembled and offered to the deities during the Annakut celebrations in 2000 at the BAPS Swaminarayan Mandir in Neasden, England.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://londonmandir.baps.org/the-mandir/|title=– BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir, London|website=londonmandir.baps.org|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref>
