{{Infobox musical composition | name = Sun of Unclouded Righteousness | type = | image = Charles Wesley.jpg | alt = | caption = Charles Wesley | translation = <!-- to English, if hymn name is a different language --> | native_name = <!-- if hymn name is the translation --> | native_name_lang = <!-- two-letter code --> | composer = | genre = [[Hymn]] | occasion = | text = [[Charles Wesley]] | language = | written = 1758 | based_on = {{Sourcetext|source=Bible|version=King James|book=Malachi|chapter=4|verse=2}} | meter = 8.8.8.8.8.8 | melody = | composed = <!-- {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}}|end_date={{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}}|location=}} --> | published = | misc = }}
"'''Sun of Unclouded Righteousness'''" is a little-known 1758 Christian hymn written by [[Charles Wesley]], the brother of [[John Wesley]], the founder of [[Methodism]].<ref name=h /> It was written as an [[intercessory hymn]] praying for the salvation of Muslims and calls for their conversion to Christianity.<ref name=j /> It had fallen out of use by around 1880.<ref name=hymnary/>
== History == [[Charles Wesley]] had a history of encouraging people to pray for the salvation of a variety of people.<ref name=j>{{cite web|first=Charles |last=Fenner |url=http://jenkins.sbts.edu/2017/02/27/charles-wesleys-hymn-of-intercession-for-arabs/ |title=Charles Wesley’s Hymn of Intercession for Arabs |publisher=Southern Baptist Theological Seminary |date=2017-02-27 |accessdate=2018-05-02}}</ref> He wrote "Sun of Unclouded Righteousness" with the subtitle of "For the [[Ottoman Empire|Turks]]" or "For the Mahometans".<ref name=imp>{{cite book | first =Jeffrey | last =Richards | title =Imperialism and Music: Britain 1876–1953 | publisher = Manchester University Press | edition = | year = 2001 | isbn = 0719061431 |page=388}}</ref> It was first published in 1758 in his ''Hymns of Intercession for All Mankind'' hymnal.<ref name=h>{{cite paper|first=Michael A.G. |last=Haykin |url=https://swbts.edu/sites/default/files/images/content/docs/journal/49_2/49.2_Haykin.pdf |title=“For those who spurn the sprinkled blood!” Praying with Charles Wesley for Muslims |publisher=Southwestern Journal of Theology |format=pdf |date= |pages= 188–198 |accessdate=2018-05-02}}</ref> It was intended as a prayer for salvation of Muslims and reflected the prevalent negative view of Islam promoted by [[Humphrey Prideaux]] in Great Britain at the time.<ref name=h /> It was written to also accompany the [[Collect]] for [[Good Friday]] in the [[Church of England]]'s ''[[Book of Common Prayer]]''.<ref name=h /> The hymn's title was based upon [[Malachi 4]]:2 where the [[Messiah]], believed to be referring to [[Jesus]] by Christians, was called the "Sun of Righteousness".<ref>{{cite book | first =Benjamin | last =Clark | title =The Domestic Sanctuary: Being a Comment Upon a Portion of God's Word for Every Day in the Year, Etc | publisher =T. Allman | edition = | year = 1847 | isbn = 1104577690 |page=314}}</ref>
Charles and his brother [[John Wesley]] had read Prideaux's work on early Islam while in Paris, and John noted that no opponents of Christianity had hurt it as much as [[Muhammad]] during the [[Early Muslim conquests]]. The hymn refers to that conquest in the line, "The smoke of the infernal cave,/Which half the Christian world o’erspread"; the "cave" mentioned there is [[Jabal_al-Nour#Cave_of_Hira|Hira]], where Islam teaches that Mohammed received [[revelation]]. Muhammad is referred to in the hymn as "that Imposter" and "that Arab Thief".<ref name=h /> Later versions of the third verse were changed to "E'en now the Moslem fiend expel, And chase his doctrine back to hell".<ref name=mo>{{cite web|url=https://hymnary.org/hymn/CHPS1866/page/544 |title=A Collection of Hymns for Public, Social, and Domestic Worship page 544 |publisher=Hymnary.org |date= |accessdate=2018-05-02}}</ref>
The hymn also engaged in polemics with regard to theological controversies of its day, namely the conflict between [[John Taylor (dissenting preacher)|John Taylor]]'s [[Unitarianism]] and Christians who held a [[trinitarian universalism]] perspective. The fourth stanza had always expressed the trinitarian universalism perspective; earlier versions of the third stanza ended with "The Unitarian fiend expel/And chase his doctrine back to hell" referring to Islam and its teaching, but also more explicitly to this controversy.<ref name=h /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://hymnary.org/hymn/CHUP1874/page/418 |title=A Collection of Hymns, for the Use of the People Called Methodists, with a Supplement page 418 |publisher=Hymnary.org |date= |accessdate=2018-05-02}}</ref> The hymn was, in the words of a commenter on it, "an implicit challenge" to send [[missionary|missions]] to those regions.<ref name=h />
== Later disfavour == "Sun of Unclouded Righteousness" largely stopped being published in hymnals around 1875.<ref name=hymnary>{{cite web|url=https://hymnary.org/text/sun_of_unclouded_righteousness |title=Sun of unclouded righteousness |publisher=Hymnary.org |date= |accessdate=2018-05-02}}</ref> However it was still published in the 1879 ''[[Methodist Hymnal]]''.<ref name=imp /> Despite Wesley's intent for it as a prayer for unbelievers, the hymn characterizes Islam negatively and expresses the stereotype of [[Arabs]] as, in the words of one commenter on the hymn, "militaristic marauders"; these elements make the hymn an embarrassment to contemporary Christians interested in inter-religious dialogue.<ref name=j />
== Lyrics == The original lyrics as written by Wesley:<ref name=mu>{{cite web|url=https://divinity.duke.edu/sites/divinity.duke.edu/files/documents/cswt/56_Intercession_Hymns_%281758%29.pdf |title=Intercession Hymns (1758) |publisher=Duke Divinity School |date= |accessdate=2018-07-24}}</ref> {{quote|<poem>Sun of unclouded righteousness, With healing in thy wings arise A sad, benighted world to bless, Which now in sin and error lies, Wrapped in Egyptian night profound, With chains of hellish darkness bound.
The smoke of the infernal cave, Which half the Christian world o'erspread, Disperse, thou heavenly Light, and save The souls by that impostor led, That Arab-thief, as Satan bold, Who quite destroyed thine Asian fold.
O might the blood of sprinkling cry For those who spurn the sprinkled blood! Assert thy glorious Deity, Stretch out thine arm, thou triune God, The Unitarian fiend expel, And chase his doctrine back to hell!
Come, Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, Thou Three in One, and One in Three, Resume thine own for ages lost, Finish the dire apostasy; Thine universal claim maintain, And Lord of the creation reign!</poem> }}

:''For the historical figure and astronomer, sometimes called Tarutius, see [[Lucius Tarutius Firmanus]] ([[floruit|fl.]] 86 BC).''
In [[Roman mythology]], '''Tarutius''' or '''Tarrutius''' was a wealthy merchant married to [[Acca Larentia]]. According to [[Plutarch]]'s ''Life of [[Romulus]]'', the keeper of the [[Temple of Hercules]] challenged the hero to a game of dice with [[Hercules]] to receive a night with a beautiful woman and a fine spread and the god to provide the temple keeper with a valuable gift if the keeper was successful.
As Hercules won the contest, the keeper procured the services of Acca Larentia for the night and provided a fine supper. In the morning, Hercules suggested that she approach the first man she met on leaving the temple. Tarutius was the man whom she met and the couple ended up marrying. Tarutius was a wealthy, older man with a large estate and is often believed to be an [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]].
Tarutius died shortly after their marriage, leaving no children. Acca Larentia inherited the estate and, when she disappeared, her will was found devoting the estate to Rome. This version is considered to be the basis for the full legal entitlement of areas claimed by Rome.
[[Augustine of Hippo]] referred to the legend in his book ''[[City of God (book)|The City of God]]'' as an example of how the pagan gods are supposed to have delighted in human sensual pleasures. In St. Augustine's version, Tarutius is held to be a younger man who Acca Larentia meets after spending the night with Hercules in a dream. Tarutius is held to have had kept Acca Larentia as his mistress for many years, leaving his estate to her on his death. She in turn leaves the estate to Rome in her will which is found when she mysteriously disappears.
==References== * Pierre Grimal, ''The Dictionary of Classical Mythology'' Blackwell Publishing, Malden Massachusetts, 1996 page 3 * [http://www.bostonleadershipbuilders.com/plutarch/romulus.htm ''Plutarch's Life of Romulus''] * St Augustine of Hippo, ''The City of God'', Penguin Classics London 1973 page 240 <!--not working * [http://www.forumromanum.org/mythology/tarutius.html Forum Romanum article on Tarutius]-->

{{Infobox song | Name = The God That Failed | Cover = | Artist = [[Metallica]] | Album = [[Metallica (album)|Metallica]] | Released = August 12, 1991 | Recorded = October 1990 – June 1991 at "One On One" studios, [[Los Angeles, California]] | Genre = [[heavy metal music|Heavy metal]] | Length = 5:05 | Writer = [[James Hetfield]]
[[Lars Ulrich]] | Label = [[Elektra Records|Elektra]] | Producer = [[Bob Rock]], [[James Hetfield]], [[Lars Ulrich]] | Tracks = #"[[Enter Sandman]]" #"[[Sad but True]]" #"Holier Than Thou" #"[[The Unforgiven (song)|The Unforgiven]]" #"[[Wherever I May Roam]]" #"[[Don't Tread on Me (Metallica song)|Don't Tread on Me]]" #"Through the Never" #"[[Nothing Else Matters]]" #"Of Wolf and Man" #"'''The God That Failed'''" #"My Friend of Misery" #"The Struggle Within" }} '''"The God That Failed"''' is a song by American [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band [[Metallica]], from their 1991 [[Metallica (album)|self-titled album]]. The song was never released as a single, but was the first song of the album to be heard by the public. It was one of Metallica's first original releases to be tuned half a step down. ==Composition and recording== Composer and lyricist [[James Hetfield]] described the song as "very nice... Slow, heavy and ugly."{{cite book |first=James|last=Hetfield|authorlink=James Hetfield|editor=Kitts, Jeff |editor2=Tolinski, Brad |editor3=Steinblatt, Harold|title=Guitar World Presents Metallica|pages=18–19|year=1997|publisher=Music Content Developers|location=Wayne, NJ|isbn=0-7935-8079-X}} Lead guitarist [[Kirk Hammett]] recalls the inception of his solo in the song: "I had this whole thing worked out, but it didn't fit because the lead was too bluesy for the song, which is characterized by real heavy riffing and chording."{{cite book |first=Kirk|last=Hammett|authorlink=Kirk Hammett|editor=Kitts, Jeff |editor2=Tolinski, Brad |editor3=Steinblatt, Harold|title=Guitar World Presents Metallica|pages=18|year=1997|publisher=Music Content Developers|location=Wayne, NJ|isbn=0-7935-8079-X}} According to Hammett, he and producer Bob Rock worked out his guitar solo on the song. Together they composed a melody to which Hammett wanted to add harmony. The producer suggested that this would make the song sound too "pretty", and instead recommended playing the melody an [[octave]] higher. The final guitar solo was put together from over a dozen performances by the guitarist during the recording of the album. Hammett calls the resulting work one of his favorite solos on the album. ==Meaning== The central theme of the song is faith and human reliance on it, and of unrewarded belief in a God that fails to [[Healing|heal]]. The lyrics and song material were inspired by [[James Hetfield|Hetfield]]'s anguish on the circumstances surrounding his mother's death.{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Sid|title=Metallica Metallica (The Black Album) Review|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/8b8c|publisher=BBC Music|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} She died of cancer after refusing medical attention, solely relying on her belief in God to heal her.[http://www.encycmet.com/songs/sbtgodtf.shtml "Song info - The God That Failed"], Encyclopedia Metallica. Hetfield felt that had she not followed her [[Christian Science]] beliefs, she could have survived.{{cite book |first=Ingham|last=Chris|title=Metallica: Nothing Else Matters: The Stories behind the Biggest Songs|pages=108|year=2003|publisher=Thunder's Mouth Press|location=New York|isbn=1-56025-536-6}} [[Baylor University]] Assistant Professor of Religion, Paul Martens points out that the song has been admired by some [[anti-religious]] groups, such as the websites "Alabama Atheist" and "[[Internet Infidels|The Secular Web]]".{{cite book |first=Paul|last=Martens|editor=Gilmour, Michael J.|chapter=Metallica and the God That Failed: An Unfinished Tragedy in Three Acts|title=Call Me the Seeker: Listening to Religion in Popular Music|pages=98|year=2005|publisher=Continuum|location=New York|isbn=0-8264-1713-2}} Martens notes, however, that Hetfield does not celebrate God's failure in the song, but instead blames God, through his mother's faith and death, for contributing to the meaninglessness of life.Martens (2005), p. 103. ==Covers== [[Finntroll]] covered this song and its included on the limited edition of [[Nifelvind]].{{cite web|last=O'Phil|first=Metal|title=Finntroll : A unique band|url=http://www.radiometal.com/en/article/finntroll-a-unique-band,107021|publisher=Radio Metal|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} In 2012, [[Black Spiders]] covered this song for the [[Kerrang!]] album Black Album Covered.{{cite web|last=Simon|first=|title=Download the artwork to this week's exclusive CD!|url=http://www.kerrang.com/blog/2012/06/download_the_artwork_to_this_w_1.html|publisher=Kerrang!|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} ==Live performance== The song was first played on the first date of the "Shit Hits the Sheds" tour (May 30, 1994). It was played in E flat tuning from 1994 to 2006 - since 2010, the song has been played in D standard tuning. It received frequent live performance during the [[2012 European Black Album Tour]] when it was played as a part of the ''[[Metallica (album)|Black Album]]''.{{cite web|last=Quellette|first=Mary|title=Metallica Power Through Black Album at Download Festival|url=http://loudwire.com/metallica-power-through-black-album-at-download-festival/|publisher=[[Loudwire]]|accessdate=June 12, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Merlin|first=|title=Download 2012 Review: Metallica, Killswitch Engage, Skindred, Biffy Clyro|url=http://www.metalhammer.co.uk/news/download-2012-review-metallica-killswitch-engage-skindred-biffy-clyro/|publisher=[[Metal Hammer]]|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book |first=Paul|last=Martens|editor=Gilmour, Michael J.|chapter=Metallica and the God That Failed: An Unfinished Tragedy in Three Acts|title=Call Me the Seeker: Listening to Religion in Popular Music|pages=95–114|year=2005|publisher=Continuum|location=New York|isbn=0-8264-1713-2}} {{Metallica}} {{Finntroll}} {{DEFAULTSORT:God That Failed, The}} [[Category:Metallica songs]] [[Category:1991 songs]] [[Category:Songs critical of religion]] [[Category:Songs inspired by deaths]] [[Category:Songs written by James Hetfield]] [[Category:Songs written by Lars Ulrich]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Bob Rock]] [[Category:Black Spiders songs]] [[Category:Finntroll songs]]

{{Pp-semi|small=yes}} '''Yosef Mizrachi''' ({{lang-he|יוסף מזרחי}}) is a [[Sephardi Jews|Sefardi]] [[Haredi Judaism|Haredi]] [[rabbi]] and founder of DivineInformation.com, an [[Orthodox Judaism outreach]] organization, based in [[Monsey, New York]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.divineinformation.com/about-rabbi-mizrachi/|title=DivineInformation.com – Torah and Science – Rabbi’s Bio|website=www.divineinformation.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref>
==Early life and career==
Yosef Mizrachi was born in 1968 in [[Israel]].<ref name=":0" /> After his mandatory military service in the [[Israel Defense Forces]] he worked in finance in New York City. In 1994, Mizrachi began dedicating himself to [[Orthodox Judaism outreach]], and in 1997, Mizrachi left his professional career and began learning and teaching [[Torah]] at Yeshivat Ohr Yisrael in Monsey.<ref name=":0" />
Mizrachi discussed his [[Semikhah]] (rabbinical ordination) credentials in a January 9, 2016 radio interview with Zev Brenner. When asked if he has Semikhah, Mizrachi stated that he lacks such Semikhah which involves testing and is common among [[Synagogue]] rabbis. However, Mizrachi went on to explain that he has received certification in recognition of his Torah background by Rabbi [[Eliyahu Ben Haim]] qualifying him to be a rabbi.<ref>{{cite interview |last=Mizrachi |first=Yosef |interviewer=Zev Brenner |title=Talkline with Zev Brenner with Rabbi Yosef Mizrachi on Holocaust Denial |type=Radio interview, online audio. Remarks beginning 59:54 minutes into the interview |publisher=Talkline Communications |date=2016-01-09 |url=https://www.mixcloud.com/zevbrenner/talkline-with-zev-brenner-with-rabbi-yosef-mizrachi-on-holocaust-denial/ |access-date=2017-02-26 |quote=ZB: And what do you have Smicha from? YM: So here is the point now, now when I learn in Yeshiva, for many years in Yeshiva, I don't have the kind of Smicha to be a rabbi in the Young Israel synagogues that in order for you to get it you need to go and bring certain documents that they tested you on such and such things. But when I started to learn in Yeshivot, and I learn- taught 10 years Gemara in Yeshiva, I got a certificate after they saw my knowledge that I have more than 10 big rabbis including the Av Beit Din signed on it that not only I'm a rabbi I'm a very big one and I'm—. ZB: Which Av Beis Din, what's the name. YM: Rav Eliyahu ben Chaim.}}</ref>
==Kiruv work== Mizrachi founded a Kiruv organization in 1995.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.divineinformation.com/about/|title=DivineInformation.com – Torah and Science – About|website=www.divineinformation.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref> The organization provides free [[DVD]]s, [[Compact disc|Audio CDs]], and [[MP3|MP3 CDs]], sponsored by donors. As of 2013, the organization has handed out thousands of these audio and video disks.<ref name="RavMizrahiAbout">{{cite web|last=Mizrachi|first=Yosef|title=About|url=http://www.divineinformation.com/about/|work=Divine Information|publisher=DivineInformation.com 2013|accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref><ref name="Arutz Sheva About Rabbi Mizrahi">{{cite web|title=About Rabbi Yosef Mizrachi|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/Radio/Author.aspx/6260|work=Radio|publisher=Arutz Sheva, IsraelNationalNews.com|accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref><ref name="ZoomInfo Rav Mizrahi">{{cite web|title=Yosef Mizrachi|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/p/Yosef-Mizrachi/406585330|publisher=zoominfo.com|accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref> Mizrachi offers an extended ethical audio and video lecture series, called "The Path of the Just",<ref name="video-pathofthejust">{{cite web|last=Mizrachi|first=Rabbi Yosef|title=The Path Of The Just Series|url=http://www.divineinformation.com/category/the-path-of-the-just-series/|work=Divine Information|publisher=Irgun Kiruv - divineinformation.com|accessdate=2 June 2013}} (21 lectures á c. 1h30min each)</ref> based on the [[musar literature|musar]] text [[Mesillat Yesharim]] composed by [[Moshe Chaim Luzzatto]].
In 2001 Mizrachi opened a [[Kolel]] and a [[Yeshiva]] in [[Solomon Eliezer Alfandari|Alfandari]] Street, Jerusalem.<ref name=":0" />
In 2002 a movie called ''Divine Information'' was produced by Mizrahi and Yuval Ovadia.<ref name="mizrahiBio">{{cite web|last=Mizrahi|first=Rabbi Yossef|title=Rabbi’s Bio|url=http://www.divineinformation.com/about-rabbi-mizrachi/|publisher=DivineInformation 2013|accessdate=19 July 2013}}</ref> Two years later, in 2004, Mizrachi launched the "DivineInformation.com" website posting many of his video and audio lectures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/Radio/Author.aspx/6260|title=About Rabbi Yosef Mizrachi - Radio - Arutz Sheva|work=Arutz Sheva}}</ref>
==Controversies==
In early 2014, before a lecture tour in [[London]], concern was expressed about statements by Mizrachi in his previous lectures relating to the behaviour of secular and religious Jews during [[the Holocaust]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RGBSkWvVdnU&feature=youtu.be&t=1h41m23s | title=Manners - The Right Way To Behave (Section on non-religious Jews during the holocaust - at 1 hour 41minutes into talk) }}</ref> suggesting that [[Down's Syndrome]] and [[autism]] are "punishments for sins committed in a previous life" and among others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejc.com/node/115021|title=Synagogue cancels talk by 'Down's Syndrome is a punishment' rabbi|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="jc">https://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/synagogue-cancels-talk-by-down-s-syndrome-is-a-punishment-rabbi-1.52154</ref> Mizrachi was criticized for his views while he explicitly maintains are "Torah sourced." His views also include lectures using [[Bible Code]]s to "explain" the Holocaust.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uSxSBN_uJOc | title=Rabbi Mizrachi - Why Did The Holocaust Happen? Torah Codes, Having Faith in God No Matter What}}</ref> As a result, at least one of his planned lectures in London was initially cancelled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/115021/synagogue-cancels-talk-downs-syndrome-a-punishment-rabbi|title=Synagogue cancels talk by 'Down's Syndrome is a punishment' rabbi|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="jc"/>
In December 2015, in one of his lectures, Mizrahi claimed that it is possible that only one million Jews died in [[The Holocaust]] as opposed to the well accepted figure of 6 million, since many of them were not Jewish according to Jewish law which requires a person's mother to be Jewish.<ref name="JP2"/><ref name="JP">{{Cite web|title = Rabbi apologizes for challenging number of Jews killed in Holocaust|url = http://www.jpost.com/Diaspora/Rabbi-apologizes-for-challenging-number-of-Jews-killed-in-Holocaust-439373|website = The Jerusalem Post {{!}} JPost.com|access-date = 2015-04-01}}</ref> Mizrahi was criticized by academics and Jewish leaders including [[Efraim Zuroff]], director of the [[Simon Wiesenthal Center]], who said that he "made up history to suit an agenda."<ref name="JP2">{{Cite web|title = Orthodox rabbi: Only one million Jews killed in Holocaust|url = http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Orthodox-rabbi-Only-one-million-Jews-killed-in-Holocaust-438890|website = The Jerusalem Post {{!}} JPost.com|access-date = 2015-12-31}}</ref> He was also criticized by [[Berel Wein]] who stated that "It is too damaging a matter to be left unanswered and unrefuted."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rabbiwein.com/blog/post-1850.html|title=THE NEWEST HOLOCAUST DENIERS: Rabbi Wein: Jewish Destiny|publisher=}}</ref> Later Mizrahi issued an apology.<ref name="JP"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iHueaPhnA6g|title=Rabbi Mizrachi apologizes to Holocaust survivor|publisher=Yeshiva World News |format=Google [[YouTube]] |work=Official channel}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X55T2aD7IXA&feature=youtu.be&t=1233|title=#1 Threat To Our Nation, Gossip, False Hate, The Media Murder Machine, 31 Violations Of Loshon Hara|publisher=Rabbi Yosef Mizrachi |format=Google [[YouTube]] |work=Official channel}}</ref> According to [[The Times]],<ref>"The Times" -September 9, 2016, page 17</ref> Chief Rabbi [[Ephraim Mirvis]] has spoken out against the travel plans of this "Jewish hate preacher"; and the UK [[Home Office]] has suggested that the [[Home Secretary]], [[Amber Rudd]], was considering banning Mizrahi should he apply to visit Britain.
A meeting with Dr. Katz and Rabbi Mizrachi concluded the controversy about the holocaust, when Rabbi Mizrachi met with the holocaust survivor. Rav Mizrachi publicly apologized to Dr. Katz, the other Jewish Nation survivors, and victims of the holocaust. Dr. katz told Rav Mizrachi that his apology was accepted chiefly because of the Rabbi's quick response to his invitation.<ref>Rabbi Mizrachi Apologizes To Holocaust Survivor https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iHueaPhnA6g</ref>
In December 2016, 16 prominent US rabbis issued an open letter about Mizrachi. They said that Mizrachi "reduce[s] complex issues to simplistic and misleading sound bites," and his assertions are "objectionable, and even dangerous."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/us-news/.premium-1.757552|title=U.S. Orthodox Leaders: Rabbi Who Said Fewer Than 1 Million Jews Died in Holocaust Is 'Dangerous'|first=Avital|last=Chizhik-Goldschmidt|date=8 December 2016|publisher=|via=Haaretz}}</ref> The letter continued that institutions should be more "discerning" with the guests they invite.

[[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]] }} '''Yugoslav Muslim Organization''' ({{lang-bs|Jugoslavenska muslimanska organizacija}}, ''JMO'') was a [[Bosniak]] [[political party]] in the [[Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes]], later in the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]]. It was founded in [[Sarajevo]] on the 16 February 1919 and was led by [[Mehmed Spaho]].https://books.google.com/books?id=L6ApcPGGyokC&pg=PA97Lopasic, Alexander. ''[https://www.jstor.org/stable/194542 Bosnian Muslims: A Search for Identity]'', in ''Bulletin'' ([[British Society for Middle Eastern Studies]]), Vol. 8, No. 2, (1981), pp. 115-125 The party was a successor of Muslimanska Narodna Organizacija (Muslim National Organization), a conservative Bosniak party founded in 1906 during the Austro-Hungarian era. The Muslim National Organization was itself a successor of the conservative Bosniak "Movement for [[waqf]] and educational autonomy" (Pokret za vakufsko-mearifsku autonomiju) that goes back to 1887. In election campaigns the JMO did mobilize on religious slogans rather than Bosniak nationality, calling failure of Muslims to vote for the party as a sin. The party had considerable influence in Islamic religious institutions, and JMO came to dominate the political life in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]]. The party appealed to Muslims throughout Yugoslavia, urging them not to migrate to [[Turkey]]'''.[http://www.yorku.ca/soi/_Vol_5_1/_HTML/Sadkovich.html Sadkovich: Reconsidering Bosnia-Herzegovina]''' In 1921 JMO aligned itself with the governing Serbian parties. JMO wanted to achieve territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina and demanded religious autonomy as well as right for the [[Sharia law]].{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} Their demands were given to the Constitutional Assembly and as a compromise those demands were accepted and incorporated in the [[Vidovdan Constitution]] under the so-called "Turkish Paragraph".{{sfn|Zovko|2006|p=68-69}} The support of JMO was important to pass the new constitution. This alliance became short-lived though. In 1922 a new Muslim party, [[Yugoslav Muslim People's Organization]] (JMNO), was formed and overtook the role as the Muslim ally of the Serbian parties. JMNO did however fail to attract any major section of the JMO vote-bank. In 1923 the party founded the cultural organization ''Narodna Uzdanica''. JMO entered into a short-lived alliance with the [[Slovene People's Party (historical)|Slovenian People's Party]] and the [[Croatian Republican Peasant Party]]. After the alliance broke down in 1925, JMO found itself politically isolated and came under attack from Serbian paramilitaries. At one time the paramilitaries attempted to kill Spaho. In 1927 the party suffered some setback in the election. After the election JMO joined a Serbian-led government. At this time the profile of JMO shifted, as it began to stress that it was a Bosnian party, rather than Muslim or Yugoslav. JMO was banned by [[Alexander I Karađorđević|Alexander I]], along with other parties. [[Mehmed Spaho]] later rebuilt the JMO and joined [[Milan Stojadinović]]’s Serbian-dominated government in 1937. He resigned in 1939 to protest the creation of the [[banovina of Croatia]]: he died a few months later and was succeeded as party chairman by [[Džafer Kulenović]]. The JMO dominated Bosnian politics until 1941.Robert J. Donia, John Van Antwerp Fine, ''Bosnia-Hercegovina: A Tradition Betrayed'', C Hurst & Co Publishers, 1994, page 108 After the [[invasion of Yugoslavia]] by Axis powers, [[Ante Pavelić]]'s [[Independent State of Croatia|quisling Croatian regime]] received support from several JMO leaders, among whom Džafer Kulenović who served as vice-president. Other JMO members supported the [[Yugoslav Partisans|Partisans]] instead ; one JMO senator participated to the first [[Anti-Fascist Council for the National Liberation of Yugoslavia|AVNOJ]] session in 1942.Stevan K. Pavlowitch, ''Hitler's new disorder: the Second World War in Yugoslavia'', Columbia University Press, 2008, p. 130-132 ==Election results== Elections results in Yugoslavia, 1920-1927[http://www.elisanet.fi/daglarsson/dokumentit/yugval1.htm YUGVAL1] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060510152731/http://www.elisanet.fi/daglarsson/dokumentit/yugval1.htm |date=May 10, 2006 }} {| class="wikitable" !Year !% !Seats |- |1920 |6.9 |24 |- |1923 |5.2 |18 |- |1925 |5.4 |15 |- |1927 |2.5 |18 |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{KoY parties}} [[Category:Islamic political parties]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1919]] [[Category:Political parties in the Kingdom of Yugoslavia]] [[Category:Islam in Yugoslavia]] [[Category:Ethnic organizations in Yugoslavia]] [[Category:Bosniak history]] [[Category:Yugoslav Bosnia and Herzegovina]]
